Award.AwardTitle: The Cost of A New Fur Coat: Interactions between Molt and Reproduction in Weddell Seals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Marine mammals that inhabit high latitude environments have evolved unique mechanisms to execute a suite of energetically-costly life history events (CLHEs) within a relatively short timeframe when conditions are most favorable. Understanding the intrinsic and extrinsic factors that regulate CLHEs is particularly important in species such as Weddell seals, as both reproduction and molt are associated with large reductions in foraging effort, and the timing and outcome of each appears linked with the other. The long-term mark recapture program on Erebus Bay's Weddell seals provides a unique opportunity to examine CLHEs in a known-history population. The proposed work will monitor physiological condition, pregnancy status, and behavior at various times throughout the year to determine if molt timing is influenced by prior reproductive outcome, and if it, in turn, influences future reproductive success. These data will then be used to address the demographic consequences of trade-offs between CLHEs in Weddell seals. The impact of environmental conditions and CLHE timing on population health will also be modeled so that results can be extended to other climates and species.

An improved understanding of the interactions between CLHEs and the environment is important in predicting the response of organisms from higher trophic levels to climate change. Results will be widely disseminated through publications as well as through presentations at national and international meetings. In addition, raw data will be made available through open-access databases. This project will support the research and training of graduate students and a post-doctoral researcher and will further foster an extensive public outreach collaboration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Marine mammals that inhabit high latitude environments have evolved unique strategies to accomplish a suite of energetically-costly life history events within the relatively short summer when prey sources are abundant and environmental conditions more benign. This project determined the factors that influenced the timing and success of two critical life history events – reproduction and molting – in mature female Weddell seals. Over the course of four austral summers, we handled females that gave birth in a given year (moms) and those that did not (skips) and then determined how reproduction influenced summer mass dynamics, hormone profiles, molt timing, diving patterns, and the probability of becoming pregnant and carrying the offspring to term.

While we initially predicted that females that skipped reproduction in a given year would do so because they were in poor condition, this was not the case. Skip females were large and fat at the onset of summer, but then lost mass through the summer as they completed the molt more quickly than moms. Skip females spent more time hauled out (i.e. not foraging) during the summer, and this increased haulout time was associated with warmer skin, less heat loss, and faster molt. Females that gave birth lost significant mass during lactation, and then foraged intensively once they weaned their pups. Their foraging efforts led to mass recovery, but also delayed the molt process relative to skip females. They then needed to spend more time hauled out later in the summer to complete their molt, were exposed to cooler and windier conditions, and faced greater thermoregulatory costs.

Not only did molt timing differ between skip and reproductive females, but aspects of the reproductive cycle did as well. Skip females ovulated earliest in the summer (mid-November), while moms ovulated approximately 35 days after giving birth. Females that pupped later in the summer ovulated later, and this was associated with a slightly lower probability of getting pregnant, and of carrying a pup to term. However, the most significant predictor of future reproductive success was prior lifetime history, not any parameter (or suite of parameters) measured in a given year. This suggests a strong genetic component to reproductive competence, a finding that we will be investigating in follow-up research project.

We were successful at using imaging ultrasound to detect very early pregnancy in females, and determined that Weddell seals do not appear to incorporate a period of embryonic diapause into their annual cycle. Instead, active gestation begins during the molting period, and well before the new fur growth is complete. This differs from the pattern seen in all other phocids. The longer period of active gestation reduces daily gestational costs, which might be critical given the relatively low rates of mass gain through the winter period. While we measured a suite of hormones known to be associated with reproduction, it was not possible to predict which females would become pregnant or carry their offspring to term based on hormone profiles, mass dynamics, or diving patterns. This suggests that environmental and/or physiological factors that most impact fetal loss rates are operant during with long polar winter, or that reproductive success is an emergent trait influenced by multiple hidden processes that were not adequately sampled in this study.

For example, summertime diving and foraging patterns did not differ much between moms and skip females. Overall, late summer foraging dives were significantly shorter and shallower than those at other times of the year. This mid-summer shallowing of dives was also associated with higher foraging success as compared to winter foraging, and may explain why seals gained mass much faster in summer than in winter. However, while there were no large differences in diving patterns, lactation was associated with a decline in tissue oxygen stores, perhaps due to a transfer or heme or iron reserves to the pup. This puts an additional stress on the diving capacity of postpartum females through the winter months, which is a time when foraging efforts of successfully pregnant moms are higher than those females that return without pups. This suggests that mid-winter prey availability may be a significant factor in population - level reproductive success (but this was not monitored as part of this study). 

Overall, this project supported 2 MSc students, 2 PhD students and 1 post-doctoral researcher. To date, 7 peer-reviewed papers have been published, with ~8 additional publications in preparation. Our vigorous outreach program was led by Ms. Alex Eilers at the Pink Palace Museum and reached ~15,000 students and teachers per project year. A children’s book “A Seal Called Patches” was published through the University of Alaska Press, and there is also a TEDX talk available online. Data from this project is archived in the US Antarctic Program Data Center. Samples are currently archived in the PI’s lab.
